Disjunction

We have seen that we can construct larger statements from smaller ones using conjunctions. In fact we can also do this by using a disjunction, this corresponds to the use of the word 'or' in English.


Example

Consider the statements:

  1. It will rain today.
  2. It will rain tomorrow.

What is the disjunction of these statements?

Solution

The disjunction of the statements reads: C:"It will rain today or it will rain tomorrow."


At this point we must make an important distinction. Reading statement \(C\) in English, it seems like it says either it will rain today or it will rain tomorrow, so it will only rain on one day. This is known as an exclusive “or” because it excluded the possibility that it rains on both days, and this is common in the English language.

This is unfortunate, because in mathematics we take \(C\) to mean: either it will rain today or it will rain tomorrow, or both. This is known as an inclusive “or”. In mathematics (unless otherwise stated) it is assumed that a disjunction is inclusive.
